description: From Middle English geste (“idle tale”), from Old French geste (“acts, exploits”), from Latin gesta (“acts, deeds”). Doublet of gest.

entries.meaning: (archaic) An act performed for amusement; a joke.
examples: I made that comment in jest; it wasn't serious.

entries.meaning: (archaic) Someone or something that is ridiculed; the target of a joke.
examples: Your majesty, stop him before he makes you the jest of the court.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A deed; an action; a gest.
examples: the jests or actions of princes

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A mask; a pageant; an interlude.

verbs.description: jest (third-person singular simple present jests, present participle jesting, simple past and past participle jested)

entries.meaning: To tell a joke; to talk in a playful manner; to make fun of something or someone.
(African-American Vernacular, Southern US) Alternative spelling of just
